content.title: Network Security Deep Dive
content.description: Advanced network security concepts and protocols

cards.front: What is the difference between IDS and IPS?
cards.back: IDS detects and alerts on threats (passive), IPS detects and blocks threats (active)

cards.front: What are the three types of firewall architectures?
cards.back:
1. Packet Filtering
2. Stateful Inspection
3. Application Layer (Proxy)

cards.front: What is a DMZ in network security?
cards.back: Demilitarized Zone - a network segment between internal network and internet for public-facing services
Dividing network into smaller segments to limit breach impact and control access between segments
Virtual Local Area Network - logical separation of networks on the same physical infrastructure

cards.front: What is NAT and its security benefit?
cards.back: Network Address Translation - hides internal IP addresses from external networks
A decoy system designed to attract and detect attackers
Techniques to detect and block Distributed Denial of Service attacks (rate limiting, blackholing, scrubbing)
Security technique where closed ports open only after receiving a specific sequence of connection attempts
Attack where attacker sends false ARP messages to associate their MAC with another IP
IEEE standard for port-based network access control (NAC)
Hardened server exposed to untrusted networks, serving as a single entry point
Creating secure zones in data centers and cloud deployments down to individual workload level

cards.front: What are the benefits of IPv6 for security?
cards.back: Built-in IPSec support, larger address space (harder to scan), improved header structure
Malicious rerouting of internet traffic by falsely announcing IP prefixes
Web Application Firewall - protects web apps by filtering HTTP/HTTPS traffic
Secure Access Service Edge - cloud-based security combining network and security functions
Technique attackers use to move through a network after initial compromise
Capturing, recording, and analyzing network traffic to detect intrusions and investigate incidents

cards.front: What is SDN and its security implications?
cards.back: Software-Defined Networking - centralized control can improve security but creates single point of failure
